items.description:
You can easily run scripts using npm by adding them to the field in package.json and run them with . Run to see available scripts. Binaries of locally install packages are made available in the PATH, so you can run them by name.
All package.json properties are exposed as environment variables:
items.title: Run scripts

items.description:
You can pass options to the command you are using in your npm script by adding like in the example below. The marks the end of options parsing, so will just ignore it and pass it to the command.
Adding the option is like executing .
items.title: Passing options to commands

items.description:
has a option which is especially useful when combining npm scripts.
Imagine you have a setup for linting your JavaScript files like the following:
Using the option reduces the output in the terminal. See this comparison.
items.title: Silent option

items.description:
npm comes with predefined lifecyle scripts which are excuted under specific conditions if they are defined in your package.json.
This will be executed automatically before your npm package is published to the registry via to check for known vulnerabilties in your dependencies.
Note: prepublishOnly is available since npm v4.0.0. See npm docs.
items.title: Lifecycle scripts

items.description:
and are also lifecycle scripts but are not executed automatically.
Therefore they can be executed simply with:
items.title: and

items.description:
These are special lifecycle scripts which can be used to run scripts automatically in sequence.
This will lint your files before running your tests. The tests will not run if linting fails. Or more generally spoken: the following script won’t be executed if one of the scripts running in sequence exits with an exit code other than 0.
Note: and scripts can also be used for your custom npm scripts. So will also run and if defined.
items.title: and scripts

items.description:
comes bundled with (Since v5.2.0) — a tool to execute package binaries. Each command is executed either from the local directory, or from a central cache, installing any packages needed in order for to run.
If the binary is already installed, it will be executed from .
But if the binary is missing, it will be installed first.
items.title: Run script with

items.description: With (Comes bundled with npm v5.2.0 or newer) and the package, you can easily try out code in different Node.js versions without having to use a version manager like , , or .
items.title: Run commands with different Node.js versions

items.description:
Sometimes it can be useful to have a local version of a package as a dependency. You can use to link one local package into another. Run in the package you want to use. This creates a global reference. Then go into your original package and run to link in the other package.
You can now use as a dependency in the package.
items.title: Link local packages

items.description:
npm supports using a shorthand for installing a package directly from a GitHub repo:
Let's target a specific commit as the main branch is a moving target:
Specify either a commit SHA, branch, tag, or nothing.
You can also install Git dependencies with semver: (Requires npm v5 or newer)
